title: Detention or Eco Club: Choosing your future - Juan Martinez

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To talk about the importance of science and math.

options.label: D
options.text: To discuss the effects of the 1992 L.A. Riots.

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of science and math.

options.label: C
options.text: The effects of the 1992 L.A. Riots.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the quote that has driven the author to this point?

options.label: A
options.text: "Once social change begins, it cannot be reversed."

options.label: B
options.text: "You cannot uneducate the person who has learned to read."

options.label: C
options.text: "Once social change begins, it cannot be reversed. You cannot uneducate the person who has learned to read. You cannot humiliate the person who feels pride. You cannot oppress the people who are not afraid anymore."

options.label: D
options.text: "We have seen the future, and the future is ours."

title: Conserving our spectacular, vulnerable coral reefs - Joshua Drew

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of creating a system of protected areas nested together like pearls on a string?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect lots of different habitats while not excluding people from their traditional fishing grounds

options.label: B
options.text: To create one big park that provides a lot of coverage for one reef system

options.label: C
options.text: To exclude people from their traditional fishing grounds

options.label: D
options.text: To make it easier for scientists to study coral reefs

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of having a system of protected areas if something bad happens to one park?

options.label: A
options.text: The other parks will become more vulnerable

options.label: B
options.text: The other parks will become less connected

options.label: C
options.text: The other parks can be reseeded from the affected park

options.label: D
options.text: The affected park will be more self-sustaining

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of conserving many different areas?

options.label: A
options.text: It ensures that only one type of habitat gets protected

options.label: B
options.text: It ensures that all the different marine habitats in Fiji are all represented

options.label: C
options.text: It makes it easier for scientists to study coral reefs

options.label: D
options.text: It makes it easier for people to access their traditional fishing grounds

multiple-choice.question: Why do scientists need to make sure the smaller parks in Fiji are connected?

options.label: A
options.text: So that they can be more self-sustaining

options.label: B
options.text: So that they can be more vulnerable

options.label: C
options.text: So that they can be reseeded from other parks

options.label: D
options.text: So that they can be less connected

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists figure out how much migration is going on among the reserves within the system?

options.label: A
options.text: By looking at how closely related the fish in each one of these small reserves in Fiji are to each other

options.label: B
options.text: By looking at how many fish are in each reserve

options.label: C
options.text: By looking at how much food is available in each reserve

options.label: D
options.text: By looking at how many people are visiting each reserve

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of looking at a variety of different species?

options.label: A
options.text: To see if what's going on with one species is what's going on with all species

options.label: B
options.text: To see if what's going on with one species is what's going on with all species, but there's no guarantee that it is

options.label: C
options.text: To see if what's going on with one species is what's going on with all species, and there's a guarantee that it is

options.label: D
options.text: To see if what's going on with one species is what's going on with all species, but only if it's a big species

multiple-choice.question: What have scientists found so far about the connectivity among the parks within Fiji?

options.label: A
options.text: There's no connectivity among the parks

options.label: B
options.text: There's a fair amount of connectivity among the parks

options.label: C
options.text: There's a lot of connectivity among the parks

options.label: D
options.text: There's no connectivity among the parks, but it's not just a big free-for-all

multiple-choice.question: Why are conservation biologists suggesting that there be enough parks in both the east and the west to keep the populations healthy?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the fish are having a hard time making it to the islands in the far east

options.label: B
options.text: Because the fish are having a hard time making it to the islands in the far west

options.label: C
options.text: Because babies born in the far west are having a hard time making it to the islands in the far east, and vice versa

options.label: D
options.text: Because the fish are having a hard time making it to the islands in the far east, but babies born in the far east are having a hard time making it to the islands in the far west

multiple-choice.question: What can lessons about reserve connectivity help across the world?

options.label: B
options.text: Help in places like Indonesia, Papua New Guinea and the Bahamas

options.label: C
options.text: Help in all places, but only if it's a big place

options.label: D
options.text: Help in all places, but only if it's a small place

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of using a variety of tools to help understand how individual parks can function together?

options.label: A
options.text: To see if the parks can function together

options.label: B
options.text: To see if the parks can function together, so that their sum is greater than their whole

options.label: C
options.text: To see if the parks can function together, so that their sum is less than their whole

options.label: D
options.text: To see if the parks can function together, but only if it's a big park

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for how to approach conversations about sex with children?

options.label: A
options.text: The author recommends avoiding the topic altogether.

options.label: B
options.text: The author suggests that parents should be honest about their own experiences with sex, including their struggles and uncertainties, to create a safe and authentic environment for their children.

options.label: C
options.text: The author thinks that kids should be shielded from conversations about sex until they're older.

options.label: D
options.text: The author recommends using scare tactics to discourage kids from engaging in sex.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on the way society has approached conversations about sex and drugs with children?

options.label: A
options.text: The author thinks it's a great idea to have open and honest conversations with kids.

options.label: B
options.text: The author believes that kids should be shielded from these conversations until they're older.

options.label: C
options.text: The author thinks that the way society has approached these conversations is ineffective and outdated, often relying on scare tactics and myths.

options.label: D
options.text: The author is neutral on the topic.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's perspective on the importance of self-acceptance and self-love, especially in relation to sex and body image?

options.label: A
options.text: The author thinks that kids should avoid talking about sex and body image.

options.label: B
options.text: The author believes that kids should be shielded from these conversations until they're older.

options.label: C
options.text: The author thinks that self-acceptance and self-love are crucial for children's development, self-acceptance, and well-being, and that honest conversations about sex and body image can help children develop a positive body image and self-esteem.

options.label: D
options.text: The author is neutral on the topic.

title: Where do good ideas come from?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the prefrontal cortex in the human brain?

options.label: B
options.text: Processing sensory information from the environment

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following cognitive biases refers to the tendency to overestimate the importance of information that is readily available?

options.label: A
options.text: Confirmation bias (overestimating the importance of information that confirms one's pre-existing beliefs)

options.label: B
options.text: Anchoring bias (overestimating the importance of the first piece of information encountered)

options.label: C
options.text: Availability heuristic (overestimating the importance of information that is readily available)

options.label: D
options.text: Hindsight bias (overestimating the importance of one's ability to predict an event after it has occurred)

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of generating new ideas or solutions by combining existing ones?

options.label: A
options.text: Divergent thinking (generating many ideas without considering their feasibility)

options.label: B
options.text: Convergent thinking (focusing on a specific goal and finding the best solution)

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral thinking (approaching a problem from a unique perspective)

options.label: D
options.text: Synectics (generating new ideas by combining existing ones)

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following learning theories suggests that people learn by observing and imitating others?

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitivism (learning through mental processes and understanding)

options.label: C
options.text: Constructivism (learning through active construction of knowledge)

options.label: D
options.text: Social Learning Theory (learning through observing and imitating others)

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the ability to understand and interpret nonverbal cues such as body language and facial expressions?

options.label: A
options.text: Emotional Intelligence (understanding and managing one's own emotions)

options.label: B
options.text: Social Intelligence (understanding and interpreting social cues)

options.label: C
options.text: Empathy (understanding and sharing the feelings of others)

options.label: D
options.text: Theory of Mind (understanding and interpreting mental states of others)

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following cognitive strategies involves breaking down complex information into smaller, more manageable chunks?

options.label: D
options.text: Elaboration (adding details to information to remember it)

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of actively recalling information from memory rather than simply re-reading it?

options.label: A
options.text: Retrieval practice (actively recalling information from memory)

options.label: B
options.text: Spaced repetition (reviewing information at increasingly longer intervals)

options.label: C
options.text: Active recall (actively recalling information from memory)

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following instructional strategies involves providing students with choices and autonomy in their learning?

options.label: D
options.text: Incentivized learning (using rewards to motivate learning)

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the ability to reflect on one's own thought processes and learning strategies?

options.label: A
options.text: Metacognition (reflecting on one's own thought processes and learning strategies)

options.label: B
options.text: Self-awareness (understanding one's own emotions and motivations)

options.label: C
options.text: Self-regulation (managing one's own emotions and behaviors)

options.label: D
options.text: Self-efficacy (believing in one's own ability to succeed)

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following learning technologies involves using digital tools to create interactive and immersive learning experiences?

options.label: A
options.text: Learning Management Systems (organizing and delivering course materials)

options.label: B
options.text: Educational games (using games to teach new skills)

options.label: C
options.text: Virtual reality (using immersive digital environments to simulate real-world experiences)

options.label: D
options.text: Augmented reality (using digital information to enhance real-world experiences)

title: How does work...work? - Peter Bohacek

multiple-choice.question: What is the unit of measurement for work and energy in the metric system?
When lifting a heavy metal cylinder, what type of work is being done?
A person applies a force of 300 Newtons to lift a metal cylinder 1/2 meter. What is the amount of work done?
What is the rate at which energy is transferred, measured in the metric system?
According to James Watt, what was the power produced by a typical work horse?
What is the unit of measurement for power in the metric system, named after James Watt?
If it takes 1 minute to lift the metal cylinder, what is the rate of work done in Watts?
If it takes 5 days for the cylinders to return to their original position, what is the power used by the clock in milliwatts?
What type of energy is stored in the grandfather clock when the metal cylinders are lifted?
How is the power used by the clock calculated when it takes 5 days for the cylinders to return to their original position?

options.label: A
options.text: By dividing the work done by the time taken

options.label: B
options.text: By multiplying the work done by the time taken

options.label: C
options.text: By adding the work done to the time taken

options.label: D
options.text: By subtracting the work done from the time taken

If it takes 5 days for the cylinders to return to their original position, what is the power used by the clock in milliwatts?
What type of energy is stored in the grandfather clock when the metal cylinders are lifted?
How is the power used by the clock calculated when it takes 5 days for the cylinders to return to their original position?

options.label: A
options.text: By dividing the work done by the time taken

title: Dance vs. PowerPoint, a modest proposal - John Bohannon and Black Label Movement

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason that we can see the speaker standing in the room?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the room is filled with a specific type of gas.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the photons in the room are bouncing off every surface, including the speaker.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the room is filled with more than 100 quintilian photons.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the speaker is illuminated by a specific type of light source.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a laser and normal light?

options.label: A
options.text: A uses different colors than normal light.

options.label: B
options.text: A uses synchronized photons, whereas normal light uses random photons.

options.label: C
options.text: A is brighter than normal light.

options.label: D
options.text: A is dimmer than normal light.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to atoms when they are cooled down to a certain temperature?

options.label: D
options.text: They enter a new state of matter called a superfluid.

multiple-choice.question: What is a superfluid?

options.label: A
options.text: A state of matter that has high viscosity or friction.

options.label: B
options.text: A state of matter that has zero viscosity or friction.

options.label: C
options.text: A state of matter that is hotter than normal matter.

options.label: D
options.text: A state of matter that is colder than normal matter.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a superfluid when it is exposed to the outside environment?

options.label: D
options.text: It immediately turns back into normal matter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "Dance Your PhD" contest?

options.label: A
options.text: To raise money for scientific research.

options.label: B
options.text: To explain complex scientific ideas using dance.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a new form of art.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of David ODI, a biomedical engineer, when working with dancers?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new form of art.

options.label: B
options.text: To build mathematical models of cell movement and use dance to brainstorm.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the movement of dancers.

options.label: D
options.text: To explain complex scientific ideas using dance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated daily waste of time due to bad PowerPoint presentations?
What is the author's proposal to reduce the national debt?

options.label: A
options.text: To drastically reduce public support for the Arts.

options.label: B
options.text: To use dancers instead of PowerPoint to explain complex ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: To use dancers to explain complex problems and reduce the number of PowerPoint presentations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's prediction for the future of communication?

options.label: A
options.text: That dancers will become obsolete as a tool of rhetoric.

options.label: B
options.text: That PowerPoint will become more powerful than dance.

options.label: C
options.text: That a new technology of persuasion will be invented.

options.label: D
options.text: That communication will become more complex.

title: How did English evolve? - Kate Gardoqui

multiple-choice.question: What was the benefit for the Celts in Britain when the Romans ruled them?

options.label: A
options.text: The Romans took their land and resources.

options.label: B
options.text: The Romans protected them from the barbarian Saxon tribes of Northern Europe.

options.label: C
options.text: The Romans taught them the Germanic language.

options.label: D
options.text: The Romans forced them to adopt the Roman culture.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the Roman Empire, and how did it affect the Celts in Britain?

options.label: A
options.text: The Roman Empire grew stronger, and the Celts were able to expand their territory.

options.label: B
options.text: The Roman Empire began to crumble, and the Romans withdrew from Britain.

options.label: C
options.text: The Roman Empire was conquered by the Celts, and they took over the entire empire.

options.label: D
options.text: The Roman Empire remained the same, and the Celts continued to live under their rule.

multiple-choice.question: What language became the common language in Britain after the Roman withdrawal?
What happened to the Germanic tribes, the Angles, Saxons, Jutes, and Frisians, after the Roman withdrawal?

options.label: A
options.text: They formed alliances with the Celts and lived in peace.

options.label: B
options.text: They sailed across the water, did away with the Celts, and formed kingdoms in the British Isles.

options.label: C
options.text: They remained in their original territories and continued to live as they had before.

options.label: D
options.text: They were conquered by the Romans and forced to adopt the Roman culture.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the language that the Saxons mixed with Old English?
What happened to the British Isles in 1066?

options.label: A
options.text: The Normans conquered the entire island and took over the government.

options.label: B
options.text: The Normans placed a Norman king on the English throne and brought French as the language of the British royalty.

options.label: C
options.text: The British Isles remained independent and continued to be ruled by the Saxons.

options.label: D
options.text: The British Isles were divided into two separate countries, with the Saxons ruling one and the Celts ruling the other.

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of the Norman Conquest on the language of the British Isles?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the adoption of the Old English language as the official language.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the adoption of the French language as the official language.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no effect on the language of the British Isles.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the creation of a new language, Anglo-Saxon.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process by which words from French and Latin were incorporated into the English language?
What is the term for the social class that spoke Old English?
What is the term for the connotation that has persisted around Saxon words?

title: DNA: The book of you - Joe Hanson

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of every human being?

options.label: A
options.text: One cell that divides into two

options.label: B
options.text: Two cells, one from each parent

options.label: C
options.text: Three cells that merge into one

options.label: D
options.text: Two cells from the same parent

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of cells in one person's body?
What is the term for the instructions found in each cell that determine what a nose is a nose, and toes is toes?
What is the name of the tiny compartment that contains the genome?
What is the estimated length of the DNA in a single cell if it were stretched out into a single thread?
What is the term for the long thread of DNA that wraps around proteins clustered into little beads called nucleosomes?
What is the estimated number of individual instructions, called genes, in the book of you?
What are the parts of the instructions that are thrown out before we end up with something useful?
What is the estimated total length of all the letters in the book of you?
What is the term for the bookmarks that tell a cell exactly which pages it needs to look up?
What is the term for the spiral structure of DNA?
What is the estimated number of chromosomes in the book of you?
What is the term for the variation in the book of you that makes each person different?
What are the parts of the instructions that are not necessary for the final product?
What is the estimated length of each chromosome in the book of you?

title: The genius of Mendeleev’s periodic table

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with creating the periodic table?
What is the significance of the dash in the first version of the periodic table from around 1870?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents a new element that has not been discovered yet

options.label: B
options.text: It indicates the atomic weight of the element

options.label: C
options.text: It shows the melting point of the element

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the conductivity of the element

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the element that Mendeleev predicted, which is now known as gallium?
What is the atomic weight of gallium?
What is the melting point of gallium?
What is the name of the element that Mendeleev predicted, which is now known as technetium?
In what year was technetium first synthesized in a cyclotron?
What is the name of the element that was discovered in 1955 and was officially named after Dmitri Mendeleev?
How many Nobel Prize winners have had an element named after them?
What honor was given to Dmitri Mendeleev in 1955?

options.label: C
options.text: An element was named after him

options.label: D
options.text: An element was discovered and named after him
